each.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: every one of two or more things or people, considered separately
each.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She had a bottle in each hand.
Grill the fish for five minutes on each side.
Each member of the team is given a particular job to do.
We each have our own skills.
When the children arrive, you give them each a balloon.
There are four bedrooms, each with its own shower and WC.
The tickets cost £20 each  (=each ticket costs £20).
You get two cookies each  (=every one of you gets two cookies).
There are 250 blocks of stone, and each one weighs a ton.
a disease that affects about 10 million people each year
I’m going to ask each of you to speak for three minutes.
each.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with each
each.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: Each is used before a singular noun with a singular verb
each.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: Each  can also be used before ‘of’ and a plural noun The verb should still be singular
Each of these people has some useful talent or experience
each.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: You usually use ‘his’, ‘her’, ‘himself’, or ‘herself’ after each
Each boy is issued with his own locker
Each of them tried it for herself
each.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: However, you can use ‘they’, ‘them’, ‘their’ etc when you do not want to say whether people are male or female
Each individual has a right to express their views
each.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: Don’t use each in negative clauses Use none
None of the answers was correct
Each of the answers was not correct
each.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: USAGE: Each, every
each.translation[0].note_box[1].items[0]: It is often correct to use either each  or  every, but they have slightly different meanings
each.translation[0].note_box[1].items[1]: Use  each when you are thinking about the people or things in a group separately, one by one
Each student came forward to receive a medal
Each time you exercise, you get a little stronger
each.translation[0].note_box[1].items[2]: Use every when you are thinking about the whole group of people or things together, with no exceptions
Every student was given a prize
You have to enter your password every time you log on
each.translation[0].note_box[1].items[3]: Don’t use each after words such as ‘almost’, ‘nearly’, or ‘not’ Use every
Not every child enjoyed the party
